item.title: integration testing bdd-style
item.description: introduction I’ve written a few integration test frameworks where the tests were written as JUnit @Test methods and defined via a fluent API that hid the plumbing from the test author. These were always executed against a mixture of locally installed & in-memory infrastructure. This worked well-enough in small development teams where the developers wrote the tests but wasn’t so good when I considered it for a larger project with a bigger team.

item.title: test your logging
item.description: I have yet to work on a project where we have attempted to test the log statements in the software & I’ve recently found myself asking why. Log statements added by different developers (sometimes guided by a woolly statement on logging in the project coding guidelines) vary in their number, style & usefulness. item.title: about
item.description: This is my blog, codecrumbs. I’m a software developer specialising in Java with a particular interest in developer testing. I started blogging mainly to help me clarify my own thoughts and perhaps remember them beyond the end of the week. In the unlikely event that it benefits someone else, that’s great.
